text:
Situation A. Marbles Game and Area Model

The Marble Game

Bucket 1 contains three marbles—one red and two green.

Bucket 2 contains four marbles—one red, one blue, one green, and one yellow.

The player draws a marble from each bucket.
• Make a prediction. Which combination of colors is most likely to be drawn?

• What are all the possible outcomes of drawing a marble from Bucket 1 and then Bucket 2?
  • Use an area model to represent the sample space.

tiles.title: Area model for outcomes of the marble game

text:
P(red, red) = 1/12

P(green,red or red, green) = 3/12

P(green, green) = 2/12

P(green, blue) = 2/12

P(red, blue) = 1/12

P(red, yellow) = 1/12

P(green, yellow) = 2/12

Situation B. More Marbles: A Closer Look at the Area Model

This area model represents another situation of drawing marbles from two buckets.

The area of the large square is 1 square unit.

In this area model,

P(RY) = 1/10,

P(RB) = 1/10,

P(GY) =4/10,

and P(GB) = 4/10.
• Which of the following cases could be the contents of the two buckets? Explain your reasoning.

Anna’s Case

Bucket 1: 2 red and 8 green

Bucket 2: 5 yellow and 5 blue

Betty’s Case

Bucket 1: 2 red and 8 green

Bucket 2: 10 yellow and 10 blue

Charles’s Case

Bucket 1: 2 red and 10 green

Bucket 2: 3 yellow and 3 blue

Devan’s Case

Bucket 1: 1 red and 4 green

Bucket 2: 3 yellow and 3 blue

Cases Anna, Betty, and Devan color combinations are possible. They all show that the ratio of red to green blocks in one bucket is 1:4, and the ratio of yellow to blue in the other bucket is 1:1. The numbers of blocks are not as important as the ratios of blocks in determining probabilities.

In Case Charles, the ratios for Bucket 2 are equivalent. However, Bucket 1 does not have equivalent ratios, so the probability is not the same.

Students may draw the area diagram to help reason about the equivalent ratios.
• Roland claims he used proportional reasoning to decide which cases would match the probabilities. Is he correct? Explain why.

Yes. To find if they are correct you would use a scale factor to see if the ratios remained the same. Each number of marbles in Bucket 1 must have a ratio equivalent to 1 red to 4 green. Each number of marbles in Bucket 2 must have a ratio equivalent to 1 yellow to 1 blue.

Situation C. Miquel Makes a Connection

Examine Miquel’s claim. Does it make sense? Explain.

Miquel’s Claim

My strategy of using the area model to determine all the outcomes is similar to the one we used to develop a strategy for multiplying fractions using brownie pans in 6th grade.

Yes. In both cases the square area is split into smaller pieces. A part of a part is found in both cases.

For example, in the case of the brownie pans, we were buying 1/2 of a pan that was 2/3 full.

In Miquel’s area model, we are finding ¼ of 1/3 of the area for each possible selection of the marbles. For example,

  • 1/3 of the area represents picking red from the 1st bucket.
  • ¼ of that 1/3 area represents picking red from the 2nd bucket.

tiles.title: Brownie pans from Grade 6 Bits of Rational, Problem 2.1
Area model for picking red from the 1st bucket
Area model for picking red from both buckets
